Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Mining Metabolic and Enzyme Databases for the Composition of Non-Canonical Pathways
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop and implement a set of algorithms for the discovery of complex metabolic pathways using information on metabolic pathways from different species available in databases such as KEGG and MetaCyc, and enzyme information available in databases such as BRENDA. The increasing availability of experimentally elucidated metabolic pathways together with the availability of enzyme functional data have ignited research in metabolic engineering and metabolomics. Recently, metabolic engineering has facilitated the production of complex pharmaceutical molecules by combining and manipulating metabolic pathways from multiple organisms. Metabolomic studies have revealed underlying causes of complex diseases and have helped diagnostic, prognostic, and treatment regimens as these evolve toward more individualized protocols. These spectacular advances have mostly relied upon laborious manual processes that are infeasible as more and more metabolic data are generated. The ability of the algorithms that will developed herein to discover known pathways will be investigated thoroughly and will include wetlab experimentation with two model studies. The studies involve niacin and shikonin, two therapeutic agents. Computational and wetlab experimentation will be conducted in parallel, with the computation feeding the experiment and the experiment providing valuable feedback for the tuning of the parameters of the corresponding algorithms. A web server will be built to facilitate the use of our tools and to widely disseminate our work in the scientific community.

The research is timely and directed toward an important area of broad scientific interest with implications extending to fields such as health and energy. The project will provide training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students. Participation in this type of research will provide graduate students with interdisciplinary training in metabolic engineering, metabolomics, systems biology, biochemistry, and molecular biology, as well as in mathematical modeling, algorithms, and computer science. The project will provide training opportunities and mentoring for women and minority graduate, undergraduate, and high school students. For more information, please visit: http://www.kavrakilab.org/projects/nsf_abi_1262491

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metabolic pathways are sequences of metabolic reactions that transform a given input compound to a desired output compound. Finding such pathways is important in the context of synthesizing new drugs or finding new ways to break down harmful compounds. Figure 1 shows an example of 7 known pathways for synthesizing a compound called 3-HP starting from a compound called pyruvate. In general, identifying biophysically plausible pathways from a starting compound to a target compound is a challenging problem, even when many reactions are known. An effective heuristic to find pathways that biophysically plausible is to ensure that many (carbon) atoms are conserved along the pathway.

We have developed a new approach to perform pathway search  that takes advantage of the modular nature of pathways: many pathways pass through the same compounds that we have termed hubs. By pre-computing all possible pathways between any pair of hub compounds, we can easily compute pathways between any pair of compounds as shown in Figure 2. We have also developed new techniques for visualization, exploration and filtering of pathways based on user-specified criteria. For instance, users can include or exclude pathways that include a particular compound or filter by the number of carbons conserved or the number of ATP molecules used (a measure of energetic efficiency).

Our algorithm above uses the carbon conservation heuristic. This heuristic depends on knowing exactly how atoms in reactants are mapped to products during a reaction. For many reactions this information is known, for many other it is not. We have also developed a new machine learning algorithm that can automatically predict such atom mappings for reactions where this information is missing. Filling in the missing atom mapping data enables the pathway search algorithm to find more pathways.

The project provided training opportunities for undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students. It provided them with interdisciplinary training in metabolic engineering, metabolomics, systems biology, biochemistry, and molecular biology, as well as in mathematical modeling, algorithms, and computer science.
